message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has extensive bruising and the lab values show prolonged PTT and normal PT, suggesting a factor deficiency. Among the options, only Factor VIII deficiency causes hemophilia A, which is characterized by prolonged bleeding time and increased bleeding after injury or surgery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's extensive bruising and tenderness to palpation suggest a problem with coagulation or clotting factors. The elevated PT and PTT suggest a problem with both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways of coagulation. Factor VIII deficiency, also known as hemophilia A, is a common cause of these findings. The other options are not associated with the same pattern of laboratory abnormalities as seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a bleeding disorder, and laboratory tests reveal a prolonged PTT and a normal PT, which is suggestive of Factor VIII deficiency (also known as Hemophilia A). The other options do not match the laboratory findings or clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s extensive bruising, tenderness to palpation, and laboratory results suggest hemophilia A, which is caused by a deficiency in Factor VIII. Factors VIII antigen deficiency and GP1b deficiency are both rare bleeding disorders. Anti-platelet antibodies can cause a decreased BT, but this patient’s BT is prolonged.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's presentation suggests hemophilia A, which is caused by a deficiency in factor VIII. The prolonged PTT and normal PT, along with the extensive bruising and bleeding time, support this diagnosis. Option B refers to von Willebrand disease, which can present similarly but would result in a prolonged bleeding time and a normal PTT. Option C refers to Bernard-Soulier syndrome, which would result in prolonged bleeding time but normal PTT and PT. Option D refers to immune thrombocytopenic purpura, which would result in a low platelet count but normal PTT and PT.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of easy bruising and the laboratory results suggest a possible von Willebrand disease or a hemophilia. Among the options, Factor VIII deficiency is the most likely. Factor VIII is important in the coagulation cascade and its deficiency can lead to bleeding and bruising. The prolonged PTT supports this diagnosis as PTT tests the intrinsic pathway, which includes factor VIII.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a bleeding disorder, and the laboratory test results show a prolonged PTT and normal PT, which is consistent with a deficiency in one of the intrinsic clotting factors. Among the options, only Factor VIII deficiency matches these findings, while Factor VIII antigen deficiency and GP1b deficiency are not associated with prolonged PTT. Anti-platelet antibodies would not cause a prolonged PTT or affect clotting factors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s presentation includes easy bruising, tenderness, and prolonged bleeding time, which is consistent with a bleeding disorder. Factor VIII deficiency, also known as von Willebrand disease, is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and can cause symptoms like those observed in this patient. The other options are not likely to cause the same symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, especially the bruising and bleeding time, suggest a bleeding disorder. Among the options, only Factor VIII deficiency (also known as Hemophilia A) fits the laboratory test results and family history. Factor VIII is essential in the coagulation cascade and a deficiency can cause excessive bleeding and bruising. Factor VIII antigen deficiency and GP1b deficiency are not associated with Hemophilia A. Anti-platelet antibodies are associated with immune thrombocytopenia, which is not consistent with this patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's extensive bruising and tenderness to palpation suggest a bleeding disorder. The normal bleeding time and prolonged PTT suggest a factor deficiency, and among the options, only factor VIII deficiency fits the clinical picture. The other options are not associated with these clinical findings.
